intro: Draba lemmonii var. incrassata, commonly known as the thick-leaved whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. This variety is characterized by its dense, basal rosette of thick, fleshy leaves and small, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in early spring. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in alpine and subalpine habitats. The plant is adapted to cold climates and is an important component of high-elevation ecosystems.
